unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Property destruction: On 11 January 2018, unidentified individuals set fire to a car in Kiev belonging to the head of an initiative group for public control over the investigation into the murder of human rights activist Iryna Nozdrovska. The fire spread to another car parked nearby. No injuries were reported.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Other: On 18 January 2018, Ukraine's parliament in Kiev has passed a bill on de-occupation of Donbas region. The supporters of the bill, including President Poroshenko, say it will help Kyiv restore control over areas in the east that are held by Russia-backed separatists. The bill defines Donetsk and Luhansk regions as 'temporarily occupied territories', contrary to the autonomy granted to them in the Minsk agreement, and labels Russia as 'aggressor'.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 25 January 2018, Ukraine presented the first cyber security centre in Kiev, strengthening its capacity to combat cyber crime. The centre was opened thanks to cooperation with Nato and the SBU.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 26 January 2018, in Kyiv, an additional 50 Canadian servicemen have arrived in Ukraine to train the country's troops as part of the UNIFIER mission, Lt. Col. Kristopher Reeves, commander of the Canadian army's Joint Task Force-Ukraine stated.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 7 February 2018, in Kiev, members of the National Corps attacked two men who were planning to distribute 'antifascist' leaflets. The victims claimed to be members of the Communist Party from western Ukraine.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 8 February 2018, a journalist was injured after gas was dispersed in the Vesti office as the National Agency for Identifying, Tracing and Managing Assets Obtained through Corruption and Other Crimes took control of the editorial offices of the Vesti newspaper in Kiev. This was done under criminal proceedings against the former minister for taxes and levies, who is accused of corruption.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 12 February 2018, State Border Guards detained Mikheil Saakashvili, the leader of the New Forces Movement Party in Ukraine and ex-president of Georgia while he was dining in a restaurant in Kiev. Saakashvili faces extradition.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 16 February 2018, 2018 Police Forces of Ukraine seized over 100 improvised explosive devices, bottles with an unidentified flammable substance, and a large amount of marijuana during the searches at the home of one Kiev resident.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 21 March 2018, an Azerbaijani journalist was attacked at his residence in Kiev by unknown persons, which resulted in several injuries.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 22 March 2018, an MP Nadia Savchenko was arrested by Security Service of Ukraine in the building of the Verkhovna Rada in Kiev - Pecherskyi on suspicion of committing such crimes as the creation of a 'terrorist' group or a 'terrorist' organization, encroachment on the life of a statesman and attempted 'terrorist' attack. She is suspected of committing these crimes in collusion with Oleksandr Ruban, who was also detained earlier.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 28 March 2018, unidentified individuals, presumably belonging to far right groups, attacked a civilian in Kiev - Pecherskyi. They sprayed pepper spray into his face after he came out the cinema building where a Docudays human rights film festival was held.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Other: On 30 March 2018, Ukraine has expelled 13 Russian diplomats from the territory of the country in connection with a nerve gas attack against former double agent Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia in Salisbury on March 4 [coded to Kiev].

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Weapons seizure: Around 20 April 2018, the Security Service of Ukraine exposed an organized group in Kiev that established the illegal export of weapons and ammunition from the ATO area. During the investigation it was established that former members of one of the volunteer battalions sent weapons and parts of ammunition for assembling and manufacturing in one of the workshops in Kiev to be used for further re-sale in the capital region and to members of criminal circles throughout Ukraine. The SBU seized four anti-tank grenade launchers, 30 grenades, two large-calibre projectiles, three kilograms of plastid, three detonators, six rifles, three automatic weapons, 37 pistols and traumatic guns and almost 15,000 ammunition rounds.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Weapons seizure: Around 20 April 2018 (as reported), the Security Service of Ukraine stopped the activities of an international group that supplied weapons to Ukraine from Europe and the United States. During the investigation it was established that a resident of Kiev had established a channel for the supply of spare parts for pistols and automatic devices which were brought into Ukraine by couriers and later assembled in workshops for use in combat. The SBU seized three machine guns, three assault rifles, two rifles, seven submachine guns, 30 pistols and revolvers, eight grenade launchers, 32 grenades, five mines, 3,240 ammunition rounds and assembly kits pistols.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Weapons seizure: On 1 May 2018, Ukrainian law enforcers have discovered a package with arms and ammunition on Trukhaniv Island in Kiev which contained four grenades, detonators, five TNT blocks, 10 projectiles for a grenade launcher, five cartridges for a rifle and about 1,500 rounds of ammunition.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Security measures: On 8 May 2018, the Security Service of Ukraine carried out searches at home of the Ukrainian Communist Party leader Petro Symonenko in Kiev and recovered campaign leaflets calling for constitutional change or government overthrow or takeover, and seized items looking like a Stechkin pistol with a silencer and 120 cartridges. Symonenko had been summoned for questioning as part of a criminal inquiry into 'actions aimed at violent change or overthrow of the constitutional system or seizure of government power' and 'high treason,' according to the SBU spokeswoman Olena Hytlyanska. Later in the day SBU officers raided the homes of senior Communists in and around Kyiv and recovered campaign materials containing banned Communist symbols.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 15 May 2018, the Security Service of Ukraine (SBU) launched a large-scale operation against the employees of RIA Novosti Ukraine accusing them of participating in a 'hybrid information war' waged by Russia against Ukraine. Its Chief Editor, Kirill Vyshinsky, who has dual Russian-Ukrainian citizenship, was detained in Kiev - Shevchenkivskyi and more than 40 agency's employees have been summoned to the SBU for interrogation.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 17 May 2018, unidentified individuals attacked a Donbas veteran in Kiev who had become famous for his travel blog, in particular, after he published a video of arguing with and spitting in the face of a pro-Kremlin Russian journalist. The victim sustained injuries to his head.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 30 May 2018, in Kiev, Ukrainian authorities detained a Ukrainian citizen, Borys Herman, accused of being recruited by Russia's secret services to organize a murder plot against self-exiled Russian reporter and Kremlin critic Arkady Babchenko. Ukraine's Security Service (SBU) says it thwarted the planned killing by working together with Babchenko to fake his death. Ukrainian authorities also said a total of up to 30 people in Ukraine had been targeted for killing as part of the alleged Russian plot. Both SBU officials and Babchenko have defended their decision to fake Babchenko's death - rejecting criticism from reporters and journalism advocates who warned that it has undermined the credibility of law enforcement agencies and independent media organizations.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Around 21 June 2018 (between 18 June - 24 June), more than 20 LGBT activists and volunteers of the March of Equality were assaulted and beaten in Kiev.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Property destruction: On 6 August 2018, unidentified individuals tried to break into the house of a TV journalist and her parents outside Kiev by breaking the door, however fled when neighbours called the police. One of the attackers was identified as a member of a Chechen criminal group and was placed on the wanted list.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Weapons seizure: On 15 August 2018, in Kiev, law enforcers uncovered an arms cache in a garage cooperative, belonging to a former Kiev-2 battalion serviceman, with a large quantity of firearms, ammunition and explosives.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 4 September 2018, in Kyiv, Serhiy Chemes, a 'hired heavy' who was charged with torturing and murdering Ukrainian anti-government protesters during Euromaidan in 2014, was sentenced to three years and three months in prison after agreeing to testify against his former accomplices

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 4 September 2018, A court in Kiev has prolonged the arrest of parliament member Nadezhda Savchenko, accused of plotting terrorist attacks, till October 30, Savchenko's lawyer Alexander Shadrin told TASS. The court thereby dismissed the lawyer's request for Savchenko's release on parole. Shadrin said the defence will protest this decision. The Ukrainian parliament on March 22 stripped Savchenko of immunity and authorized her detention and arrest. First, Savchenko was detained and arrested for two months. The arrest was prolonged again and the request for easing the restrictive measure was turned down. Investigators suspect Savchenko of plotting terrorist attacks inside the parliament's building and the government compound in Kiev.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 6 September 2018, in Kyiv, unidentified youth group stabbed a young man 3 times with knife due to him looking 'gay'. 5 suspects were detained.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 6 September 2018, The head of the National Police, Serhiy Knyazyev, has said that Russia arms rebels in east Ukraine with weapons seized during the annexation of Crimea. Over these four years, police have registered 60 cases of seizing Crimean weapons from rebels, including 51 assault rifles, 15 pistols, two grenade launchers and one carbine. Police have opened a criminal case against the Russian Federation according to Part 2, Article 438 of the Criminal Code on using internationally illegal warfare methods.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 9 September 2018, in Kyiv, an arms cache was uncovered by police in Kiev, the Interfax-Ukraine news agency reported on 9 September. It contained four grenade launchers, 2 kg of explosives and 200 AK rifle cartridges, the Kiev police said. According to police information, the weapons were brought to Kiev by an army volunteer in 2014-16.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 12 September 2018, in Kyiv, official start of procedures of creation Ukrainian (national) Orthodox Church. The event signifies a peak of struggle of Ukrainians to break away from religious monopoly of Moscow. Metropolitan Emmanuel of France, a hierarch of the Ecumenical Church of Constantinople, told the Italian Catholic agency SIR that the procedures for creating an autocephalous local [national] Church in Ukraine had begun.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 18 September 2018, in Kyiv, Kiev police have detained a man suspected of selling weapons illegally brought from the combat zone in Donbass. The man was detained while trying to sell an AKSU rifle, two hand grenades, two grenade launchers and two Skorpion submachine guns.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: From 25th to 29 September 2018, UAF conducts military drills 'Kozatska Volia 2018' in various regions of Ukraine.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 28 September 2018, in Kyiv, around 30 young men, most of whom had Sich insignia on their clothes, present in the courtroom during the trial of a journalist being accused of treason. The SMM heard the young men verbally insulting the journalist and his defence team and saw small objects being thrown at them. Later, ten police officers in riot gear entered the courtroom, at which point the disruptions ceased.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 29 September 2018, in Kyiv, the office of a member of parliament had been damaged by unidentified people.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 26 October 2018, unidentified individuals attacked a member of Radical Party near his house in Kiev. They broke his nose and jaw and caused him a concussion. The party connects the attack to the victim's protest activity.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: As reported on Nov. 28 2018, in Kiev, the Security Service of Ukraine uncovered an organised group, which was assembling and illegally selling weapons, and seized 8 illegal firearms. Members of the group included a National Guard serviceman who was arrested.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On Nov. 29 2018, after the arrest of the Ukrainian blogger Oleksandr Baraboshko in Kiev, Ukraine, members of the military prosecutor's office inflicted light bodily injuries on him and tried to obtain evidence by force.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 30 November 2018, unidentified individuals followed to the house and tried to stab a Donbass veteran and members of Traditions and Order in Kyiv. The attackers cut the veteran's face and clothes with a knife and escaped.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Around 06 December 2018, the draft law on the termination of the treaty of friendship between Ukraine and the Russian Federation was adopted in the Vekhovna Rada in Kiev.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: As reported on Dec. 13 2018, in Kiev, the Security Service of Ukraine uncovered an organised group, which was illegally preparing, re-equipping and selling weapons, and seized 20 illegal firearms and 2500 rounds of various types of ammunition. Participants of the group included active members of the Podilskyy district directorate of the National Police in Kiev.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: As reported on Dec. 14 2018, the Security Service of Ukraine confiscated 21 F-1 hand grenades, 3 RGD-5 grenades, 15 grenades for a VOG underbarrel grenade launcher and over 3 kg of TNT from a man near Kiev, Ukraine.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On Jan. 22 2019, an unidentified person acted aggressively towards electioneers of the People's Front party and completely demolished their campaigning tent near the Palats Ukrayina metro station in Kiev.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On Feb. 1 2019, at night, an unidentified person fired a gunshot at the windows of the regional office of the National Union of Journalists of Ukraine in the Kiev city centre.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 12 February 2019, unidentified individuals broke the window of a car of the Kiev city council from Svoboda party and the head of Sokil in Kiev, threw incendiary mixture inside and set it to fire. The car burned down, no injuries were reported.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 22 February 2019, unidentified persons burned down a car of a journalist in Kiev, Ukraine. No injuries or fatalities were reported. The journalist blames a military prosecutor who previously threatened him with beating or burning his car for writing posts about the prosecutor and his family.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: As reported on 6 March, the police seized six pistols, four carbines, a sniper rifle, seven RGD-5 grenades, an anti-personnel mine, 642 grams of plastic explosive and 448 rounds of ammunition from a group of people in Kiev, Ukraine.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 18 March 2019, an unidentified person threw incendiary mixture setting fire to a 'Roshen' store [a corporation belonging to President Poroshenko] in the centre of Kiev. No injuries or fatalities were reported.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 21 April 2019, an unidentified man pushed a police officer away from a police car, sat in a vehicle and ran over the officer causing her serious injuries in central Kiev. The man was arrested.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 4 May 2019, a son of a former deputy mayor of Horlivka and now a member of the DPR government was shot dead in his apartment in Kiev.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 26 August 2019, unidentified individual fired grenade launcher at an office building in central Kiev. The building was damaged, no injuries or fatalities were reported. One of the offices that received the most impact from the explosion belongs to a former Parliament's deputy from the Party of Regions; another one belongs to Ukraine's largest bridge construction company.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 29 August 2019, a former Ukrainian soldier attacked and beat an openly gay Donbass veteran in central Kiev.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 7 September 2019, Ukraine and Russia exchanged 35 prisoners from each side. Among the prisoners released by Russia are Ukrainian filmmaker Sentsov and 24 Ukrainian sailors whose imprisonment sparked numerous demonstrations in Ukraine. Among those handed over to Moscow are Ukrainian and Russian citizens involved in the conflict in Eastern Ukraine including a witness in MH17 commercial flight downing case.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 1 October 2019, the Trilateral Contact Group on Ukraine agreed on the so-called 'Steinmeier formula' during the negotiations in Minsk that foresees that a law on the special status of Donbass comes into force from the day the non-government-controlled Luhansk and Donetsk hold democratic elections in accordance with the Ukrainian law and OSCE standards. The parties also agreed to start the disengagement of forces in Zolote and Petrovskoye areas on 7 October [coded to Kiev, Ukraine].

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 24 October 2019, three people beat up a Stop Corruption activist in Kiev.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 8 November 2019, a group of people in military uniform broke into an attorney's house in Kyiv Region, beat and tied down him and his family, including his child, and stole his case files.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 13 November 2019, at night, four unidentified people shot several times at windows of a shop of a Russian footwear brand and painted an ethnic slur in front of it.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 1 December 2019, unidentified individuals fired at the car of a Kyiv regional council deputy from European Solidarity party in central Kyiv when he and his family were inside. The bullet killed a 3-year-old son of the deputy. The deputy was previously accused of affiliation with businesses that finance rebel groups in Eastern Ukraine. Two arrested suspects used to fight on the side of the Ukrainian military in Donbass.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 12 March 2020, unidentified individuals set fire to a car of the acting head of State Environmental Inspectorate near his apartment in Kyiv. The car was destroyed, no injuries were reported. The victim connects the arson to his activities as the state official, in particular his high fines for polluters and anti-corruption measures.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Security measures: On 17 March 2020, the government of Ukraine in Kiev enacted measures to limit the spread of coronavirus - including a ban on gatherings exceeding 10 people and shutting down stores and other public places except those that sell food or medicine. On 22 May 2020, the government of Ukraine eased the quarantine restrictions.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 14 April 2020, in Kyiv, the Security Service of Ukraine (SBU) counterintelligence arrested an SBU major general Shaitanov on charges of high treason: spying for the Russian FSB and arranging attacks on Ukrainian volunteers as part of the FSB's reconnaissance and sabotage operations inside Ukraine.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 7 May 2020, according to the victims, two Donbas veterans from the Azov Battalion were severely beaten by members of National Corps in Kyiv for their support of Serhiy Sternenko - a former member of Right Sector who stabbed in self-defence one of his attackers during the third attack on his life. The leader of National Corps denies these accusations, although confirms the meeting with the two veterans.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Property destruction: On 10 July 2020, members of an anarchist group set fire to a police department in Kiev-Pecherskyi. No injuries were reported.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 17 July 2020, an unidentified explosive device went off near a metro station in Kiev-Shevchenkivskyi. One person was severely wounded, three others received minor injuries.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 21 July 2020, two Donbas veterans doused an MP from Opposition Platform - For Life party with a chemical disinfectant Zelyonka and threw eggs at him outside the Parliament in Kiev-Pecherskyi for his words that Ukraine does not have sovereignty.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Defusal: On 9 August 2020, the police defused an IED planted near an office of the Opposition Platform - For Life party in Kiev-Pecherskyi.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 25 August 2020, members of Patriots - For Life organisation shot at a group of Donbas veterans from Azov Battalion in Kiev-Pecherskyi wounding one of them.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Property destruction: On 28 August 2020, unidentified individuals set fire to a car of a member of Parliament from the Servant of the People party in Kiev. No injuries were reported.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 16 October 2020, unidentified individuals severely beat in Kiev a Ukrainian activist and Donbas veteran who was imprisoned by DPR for almost 3 years.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 30 October 2020, an unidentified individual attacked with a knife or a piece of glass a journalist near his house in Kiev and cut his face.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Weapons seizure: On 26 November 2020, the police found and seized a cache of weapons in Kiev-Pecherskyi, including four grenade launchers, two assault rifles, almost 40 grenades, several pistols, two artillery shells, and a large number of cartridges for assault rifles.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 4 December 2020, an unidentified person attacked and beat a LGBT activist in Kiev-Pecherskyi. The victim connects the attack to his recent activities in support of LGBT community.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Security measures: On 9 December 2020, the government of Ukraine in Kiev enacted measures to limit the spread of coronavirus - including shutting down stores and other public places except those that sell food or medicine.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 24 March 2021, unidentified persons abducted and killed in Kiev a veteran of the war in eastern Ukraine. The alleged reason could be that he was systematically combating raiders who were illegally occupying other people's flats in Kiev. Police started a criminal case.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Property destruction: On 18 April 2021, unknown individuals damaged the doors of the reception office of the Democratic Axe Party in Kiev and poured paint on them. unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 18 May 2021, a police officer severely beat underage youths while detaining them in Kiev.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 19 May 2021, police severely beat and detained an artist in Kiev. According to the victim, he had his nose smashed for no reason and was kept outside for several hours.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 4 June 2021, unidentified individuals attacked the deputy chairman of the National Agency for Identifying, Tracing and Managing Assets Obtained through Corruption and Other Crimes in Kiev, when he was off duty. The victim sustained a gunshot wound.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 30 June 2021, unidentified individuals, allegedly far-right activists attacked and beat in Kiev a former Kharkiv separatist, who has several times avoided attending the trial for kidnapping during the Revolution of Dignity.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 24 August 2021, an unidentified individual poured brilliant green [chemical desinfectant, Zelyonka] on former Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko in Kiev. The victim was hospitalized with burns to his eyes.

The attacker was detained.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 30 September 2021, an unknown individual fired at the vehicle of a Head of the State Archive Service in Kiev who was not in the car at the moment of the attack. His driver was wounded in the incident and hospitalized.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Property destruction: On 22 October 2021, an unidentified individual tried to set fire to the house of the deputy head of the Office of the President in charge of European integration in Kiev with a Molotov cocktail.

notes: On 6 January 2022, officers of Ukrainian Special Forces broke into an apartment and beat activists of Democratic Choice of Kazakhstan in Kiev, accusing them of coordinating the protests in Kazakhstan.

notes: Other: On 14 January 2022, a massive cyber attack was carried out against Ukrainian information resources [coded to Kiev]. Some of the websites were disabled to prevent the spreading of the attack to other resources.

unesco_site: L'viv  the Ensemble of the Historic Centre
notes: Property destruction: On 3 February 2018, unidentified people set on fire a pro-Russian Orthodox church in Lviv - St Prince Volodymyr's Church of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate. The church sustained damage.

unesco_site: L'viv  the Ensemble of the Historic Centre
notes: Property destruction: On 14 February 2018, an unidentified attacker set fire to a Russian bank branch office in Lviv. The man broke the window and threw a petrol bomb inside. The fire partially destroyed the property of the bank, but no-one was injured.

unesco_site: L'viv  the Ensemble of the Historic Centre
notes: On 2 May 2018, after a lecture at a bookstore in Lviv, a JTO serviceman and an activist of the Ecological Platform organization, Rodion Bagaev, was beaten up by a group of six men belonging to ultraright groups. The attackers were identified as members of the National Corps Party and National Militia. According to other activists of the Ecological Platform, similar attacks by the same men happened before during other leftist events in Lviv.

unesco_site: L'viv  the Ensemble of the Historic Centre
notes: On 23 June 2018, a group of masked far right men attacked a Roma camp near Lviv, Ukraine. The attackers killed one person, while four more, including a 10-year-old child, were hospitalized with stab wounds. Eight individuals were detained.

unesco_site: L'viv  the Ensemble of the Historic Centre
notes: On 18 September 2018, in Lviv, 57 out of 84 regional councillors approved region-wide ban on Russian language.

unesco_site: L'viv  the Ensemble of the Historic Centre
notes: On 28 November 2018, at night, unidentified individuals threw incendiary mixture into two separate offices of a Russian bank in Lviv. The buildings were damaged, no injuries were reported.

unesco_site: L'viv  the Ensemble of the Historic Centre
notes: On 14 February 2019, two unidentified individuals broke the window of a Russian bank in Lviv and threw a bottle with incendiary mixture inside. The fire destroyed part of the room, no injuries were reported.

unesco_site: L'viv  the Ensemble of the Historic Centre
notes: On 20 March 2019, unidentified individuals set fire to a branch office of a Russian private bank in Lviv. The office was partially damaged but no one was injured.

unesco_site: L'viv  the Ensemble of the Historic Centre
notes: On 8 July 2019, in Lviv, guards of the public enterprise Ukrainian Association of the Blind beat an attorney who had been previously appointed as a head of the association. According to the victim, he was beaten for his previous legal work in revealing labour law violations and corruption in the association.

unesco_site: L'viv  the Ensemble of the Historic Centre
notes: On 16 September 2019, unidentified individuals set fire to the front door of a flat of an employee of the mayor administration department of the city council in Lviv. No injuries were reported.

unesco_site: L'viv  the Ensemble of the Historic Centre
notes: On 30 January 2020, at night, unidentified individuals set fire to a car of a Radio Free Europe journalist in Lviv. The car was destroyed, no injuries were reported.

unesco_site: L'viv  the Ensemble of the Historic Centre
notes: Property destruction: On 10 June 2020, unidentified individuals broke into the yard of a journalist, the director-general of the NTA television channel and the Vholos media holding company in Lviv region, damaged his car and tried to break into his house but were stopped by the security system.

unesco_site: L'viv  the Ensemble of the Historic Centre
notes: On 17 November 2020, three unidentified individuals attacked and severely beat two activists of veteran movement in Lviv. The attackers were detained by police.

unesco_site: L'viv  the Ensemble of the Historic Centre
notes: On 19 November 2020, fifteen far right activists attacked and severely beat an eco-anarchist and anti-fascist in Lviv. The victim was hospitalized and had two surgeries.

unesco_site: L'viv  the Ensemble of the Historic Centre
notes: Property destruction: On 17 December 2020, unidentified individuals set fire to a car of an employee of the National Anti-Corruption Bureau in Lviv. The car was destroyed, no injuries were reported. The victim claims that the arson is connected to his professional activities.

unesco_site: L'viv  the Ensemble of the Historic Centre
notes: On 19 January 2021, unidentified people attacked an anti-fascist activist in Lviv. The attackers were armed with rubber truncheons, knives and hammers. This is the third attack on the victim, which he connects with his anti-fascist activities.

unesco_site: L'viv  the Ensemble of the Historic Centre
notes: Weapons seizure: On 23 September 2021, the Security Service of Ukraine found and seized a cache of weapons in Lviv region, consisting of 2kg of plastic explosives, TNT bombs, explosive devices, three RG-42 and F-1 hand grenades, stun grenades, electric detonators, and more than 100 cartridges of 5.45mm calibre.

unesco_site: L'viv  the Ensemble of the Historic Centre

unesco_site: L'viv  the Ensemble of the Historic Centre

On 1 January 2018, a well-known human rights activist was run over by a car in Odessa. The victim was seriously injured and hospitalised. Activists believe that he was run over deliberately due to his investigation into the degrading treatment of prisoners in an Odessa penitentiary.

On 20 January 2018, during arrest, pro-Russian individual opened fire at Ukrainian Police in Odessa. The suspect was accused in organizing anti-Ukrainian riots in 2014. One policeman and the shooter were killed. 4 people sustained injures. Two other suspects were arrested.
On 7 February 2018, a former head of the Odessa regional branch of the Ukrainian far-right Right Sector party, Serhiy Sternenko, was attacked outside his home.

Property destruction: On 21 February 2018, there was an arson attack on judge Oleksandr Dzhaburiya's car in Odessa. The press service of the court in which Dzhabiriya is working stated that the incident was linked to the judge's professional activity.
On 23 February 2018, an unknown person sprayed pepper gas in the face of Odessa regional councillor.

Weapons seizure: On 7 March 2018, the Security Service of Ukraine has exposed an extensive network used to trade in arms brought from the security operation in Donbass, organized by resident of Uman, Cherkasy Region. The suspect was detained while receiving another parcel with a pistol. Law enforcers found two Nagan pistols, a Kalashnikov rifle and various types of ammunition while searching his flat in Odessa Region.
Property destruction: On 24 March 2018, unidentified individuals tried to set up a fire at the Polish cultural centre Poska Nuta in Odessa. Fire slightly damaged the door of the cultural centre.

Weapons seizure: Around 29 March 2018, the SBU uncovered an illegal channel of arms trade in Odessa Region allegedly organised by a local resident receiving the arms from Donbass. Pistols, grenades and ammunition were seized from him during the search.

Weapons seizure: Around 7 April 2018 (as reported), the Security Service of Ukraine jointly with the police seized a large arsenal of weapons and ammunition in Odessa. While conducting 11 searches, law enforcers seized a Makarov pistol, two Walther pistols, a Mosin rifle, a machine-pistol, a Zbroyar Z-10 carbine, more than 1,000 rounds of ammunition of various calibres, and semi manufactures for producing improvised firearms.
On 25 April 2018, unidentified individuals attacked and beat the deputy head of the department of consumer market development of the city council in Odessa.

On 1 May 2018, a former head of the Odessa regional branch of the Ukrainian far-right Right Sector party, Serhiy Sternenko, was attacked with a rubber-bullet pistol. Sternenko was shot in the head, but his life is out of danger. Two suspects are detained during police investigation of the attack.
On 2 May 2018, unidentified 'radicals' beat up a man who was laying flowers during the so-called march of Ukrainian order in central Odessa commemorating deadly fire in Odessa on 2 May 2014.

Weapons seizure: Around 4 May 2018, while performing an antiterrorist raid in Odessa, border guards and police officers discovered an arsenal of firearms, including automatic, cold weapons and about 5,000 rounds of ammunition of different calibres.

On 6 May 2018, in Odessa, a woman was attacked by an unknown young man, accompanied by another man, who called her a 'separatist' and struck her face twice, cutting her upper lip. The woman was subsequently transported to a hospital.
On 24 May 2018, two men armed with knifes attacked the former leader of the Odessa branch of the Right Sector Serhiy Sternenko. Serhiy Sternenko killed one of the attackers while defending himself.
On 5 June 2018, an unidentified attacker shot the Chornomorsk city council official several times with an automatic pistol in Odessa oblast, Ukraine.

On 5 June 2018, two men armed with knives attacked a leader of Odessa Automaidan and a member of the Public Control Council of the National Anti-Corruption Buro Vitalii Ustymenko in Odessa, Ukraine. Vitalii received a puncture wound, a stab wound, a head injury and a concussion.
On 8 June 2018, three unidentified perpetrators knocked of the feet and beat a journalist Kostyantyn Hrechanyy in Odessa, Ukraine.
On 24 June 2018, an explosive device planted in a car exploded in Odessa, Ukraine. One civilian was wounded.
On 16 July 2018, two members of the local municipal guard police forces pepper sprayed and beat three journalists in Odessa.

On 2 August 2018, in an apparent planned attack, a lorry deliberately crashed into a car occupied by two activists, including a journalist and leader of the People's Movement of Ukraine and an anti-corruption activist, in Odessa. The lorry driver escaped with an accomplice on a motorbike waiting nearby. No injuries were reported.
On 21 August 2018, in Odessa, an unidentified individual approached a car of a deputy head of a communal government services provider and shot at him several times. The victim was hospitalised.

On 5 September 2018, in Odessa, unidentified person shot with small firearms at renown activist Andriy Vagapov, the victim sustained injures to his legs and was hospitalized. Vagapov is a lawyer and member of public coordination council of National Police in Odessa Region.
On 6 September 2018, in Odessa, Police and SBU found stash of 18 ground-to-air rockets as an outcome of a special operation.
On 22 September 2018, a prominent pro-Ukrainian activist, who heads local branch of Strength of People Party, was shot and badly wounded by an unidentified man in Odessa.
On 26 September 2018, unidentified individuals set fire to a car of a deputy of the regional state administration from the Opposition Bloc party near Odessa. No injuries were reported.
On 6 October 2018, unidentified individuals fired a shotgun several times at the car of an AutoMaidan activist in Odessa. The activist was injured.
On 21 January 2019, an explosive device went off near a restaurant in Odessa, Ukraine, wounding one man.

On 17 February 2019, unidentified individuals set fire to the car of an activist fighting against illegal construction in Odessa. The car burned down, the house of the activist was damaged, no injuries were reported.

On 17 February 2019, unidentified persons set fire to a car of an activist who protests against illegal construction in Odessa. A door of his house caught fire from the car. No injuries or fatalities were reported.

On 5 March 2019, unidentified individuals set fire to a car of a Bilhorod-Dnistrovskyy district councillor in Odessa. No injuries or fatalities were reported. The councillor believes that the arson is linked to his activities aimed at protecting the seaside in the resort village of Zatoka.
As reported on 7 March, the police seized five hand grenades, a hand anti-tank grenade, an AKM rifle, 58 rounds of assorted ammunition and a silencer from a man in Odessa.

As reported on 26 March, the Security Service of Ukraine seized weapons, including 36 missiles, RPG-7, RPG-18 and RPG-22 grenade launchers, TM-62M anti-tank mines, MON-100 anti-personnel mines and 200kg of TNT slabs, from an armed group in Odessa.

On 30 March 2019, after a car hit three National Guard soldiers in Odessa, killing one of them and severely wounding the other two, an unidentified man approached the victims and started beating them [fatality not coded being a result of a road accident].

On 17 April 2019, about 20-30 people attacked a weigh station at the entry to Odessa after the power was cut off around it. They beat with bats and shot rifles at four road inspectors and about 10 members of the Ukrainian Transport Union. Five people were injured, two of them were in critical condition.
On 1 June 2019, police officers severely beat two Ukrainian citizens in Odessa in an attempt to elicit a confession.

On 16 July 2019, a man was shot in his leg by a soldier in a restricted area of an anti-aircraft missile battalion in Odessa. The man, who allegedly attempted to steal technical equipment, sprayed tear gas when he saw soldiers approaching and tried to run away.
On 17 October 2019, two people beat a deputy of a town council in Odessa, the deputy sought medical assistance.
On 20 November 2019, unidentified individuals set fire to a private car of a police officer outside a police department in Odessa. The car was damaged, no injuries were reported.
On 26 November 2019, an unidentified individual set fire to a private car of the acting head of the border patrol in Odessa. The car was destroyed, no injuries or fatalities were reported.
On 1 December 2019, an unidentified individual sprayed with pepper spray and beat a local journalist near his block of flats in Odessa. The same journalist was shot at in 2012 and abducted in 2014.
On 16 December 2019, an unidentified individual set fire to a car in Odessa belonging to a regional council deputy closely affiliated with the city mayor. No injuries were reported.
On 18 December 2019, two unidentified individuals set fire to a shop in Odessa belonging to a regional council deputy closely affiliated with the city mayor. No injuries were reported.

As reported on 3 February, in Odessa, prison guards let two convicts into another prisoner's cell and did not intervene when they started beating him. After that, the guards put the beaten man in a solitary confinement where he died from injuries.

On 3 April 2020, unidentified individuals set fire to a car of an activist of Right Sector and a nationalist movement 'Street Front' in Odessa. The victims claims that the arson is connected to his activism.

Property destruction: On 11 June 2020, unidentified individuals set fire to the car of an attorney in Odessa who was defending a suspect in the acid attack on activist Kateryna Handziuk. No injuries were reported.

On 9 July 2020, an unidentified individual attacked an activist in Odessa. The victim was hospitalised with concussion and light injuries. He connects the attack with his active participation in protests against the construction in the coastal areas of the city.
On 4 August 2020, unidentified individuals threw several grenades at a car of the head of the local branch of an anti-corruption NGO in Odessa. No injuries were reported.
Property destruction: On 21 October 2020, unidentified individuals destroyed two campaigning tents of the European Solidarity party in Odessa.

Property destruction: On 21 November 2020, unidentified individuals broke the windows and set fire to a car of an activist in Odessa. The activist previously received threats for his participation in demonstrations against illegal construction in the city. No injuries were reported.

Property destruction: On 18 June 2021, unidentified individuals set fire to the activist's garage in Odessa. As a consequence, only the vehicle was damaged. Police officers assume that it was connected to the victim's anti-corruption activities.
On 5 November 2021, unidentified people attacked a deputy of one of the territorial communities in Odessa region. The victim was hospitalized.

Property destruction: On 15 December 2021, an unemployed resident from the Transnistrian region of Moldova, recruited by Russian special services (coded as FSB) set fire to the KamAZ military vehicle on the territory of the military unit of the Armed Forces of Ukraine in Odesa, Odesa. The man was convicted to 8 years of prison in 2022.
On 24 February 2022, the military forces of Russia launched a rocket attack on Odesa, starting full-scale aggression against Ukraine. There were no injuries or fatalities.

On 24 February 2022, military forces of Russia launched a rocket attack on the different districts of the city and the Military base of the National Guard in Odesa. As a result of the shelling, 22 servicemen were killed.
On 25 February 2022, there was an armed clash between the Russian military forces and the Ukrainian military forces near Odesa. Injuries or fatalities unknown.

On 5 March 2022, Ukrainian air defence forces shot down two Russian fighter planes in the Odesa region. The pilots were captured and taken for interrogation.

Interception: On 18 March 2022, Ukrainian air defense shot down a Fokus Russian guided missile in the Odesa oblast. Casualties unknown.

On 7 August 2024, Russian forces conducted a drone strike at Odesa. Casualties unknown.

The was later arrested in Odesa for carrying out arsons on six military vehicles in Kyiv, Odesa, and Dnipro (coded separately).

Interception: On 8 August 2024, Russian Forces launched two Kh-59 cruise missiles and four Shahed-136/131 drones on targets in Ukraine. Some of the missiles and drones were intercepted by Ukrainian Forces in Odesa region (coded to Odesa, Odesa). No casualties.
Interception: On 11 August 2024, Ukrainian forces shot down Russian drones over Odesa region (coded to Odesa).
On 14 August 2024, Russian forces conducted a missile strike on port infrastructure in Odesa, Odesa. Two civilians were wounded.

Interception: On 21 August 2024, Ukrainian military forces intercepted 50 Russian kamikaze-drones and a missile (coded to Kyiv) over several regions, some over the Odesa region (coded to Odesa, Odesa).
On 26 August 2024, Ukrainian military forces intercepted Russian missiles and drones over Odesa, Odesa. 4 civilians, including a child, were injured.

Interception: On 1 September 2024, Ukrainian forces shot down Russian missiles and drones over Odesa region (coded to Odesa).
