No casualties.

On 29 October 2024, Russian Forces launched 8 Shahed-136/131 type drones at targets in Ukraine from Primorsko-Akhtarsk district, Russia. Ukrainian Forces intercepted some of the drones over Mykolaiv region (coded to Mykolaiv, Mykolaiv). The fallen debris of the downed drones damaged an administration building, an educational institution and a house. No casualties.
Interception: On 3 November 2024, Ukrainian forces shot down Russian drones over Mykolaiv region (coded to Mykolaiv).

Interception: On 4 November 2024, Russian Forces launched 80 strike drones of Shahed and unidentified types at targets in Ukraine. Ukrainian Forces intercepted 50 drones, some of them over Mykolaiv region (coded to Mykolaiv, Mykolaiv). No casualties.

Interception: On 7 November 2024, Ukrainian forces engaged Russian drones, including Shahed drones, above Mykolaiv Oblast (coded to Mykolaiv, Mykolaiv.) 74 Russian drones were destroyed and 25 others were misdirected or lost above Mykolaiv, Kherson, Kyiv, Sumy, Poltava, Kharkiv, Kirovgrad, Zhytomyr, Cherkasy, and Chernihiv Oblasts.

On 8 November 2024, from Russian-held Crimea, Russian forces carried out a missile strike with an 'Iskander-M' an unidentified target in the outskirts of Mykolaiv city (coded to Mykolaiv city, Mykolaiv). Casualties unknown.

Interception: On 8 November 2024, at night, Ukrainian air defense forces shot down in total 4 Russian 'Kh-59/69' type cruise missiles and 62 attack drones over the multiple locations, some over the Mykolaiv region (coded to Mykolaiv, Mykolaiv region). Also, 23 more Russian drones were lost likely due to Ukrainian EW systems. No casualties.
Interception: On 10 November 2024, Ukrainian forces shot down Russian drones over Mykolaiv region (coded to Mykolaiv).

Interception: On 11 November 2024, at night, Ukrainian air defense forces shot down in total 2 Russian 'Kh-59/69' type cruise missiles and 39 attack drones over the multiple locations, some over the Mykolaiv region (coded to Mykolaiv, Mykolaiv region). Also, 30 Russian drones were lost likely due to Ukrainian EW systems, 3 more Russian drones left the Ukrainian airspace towards Belarus and the temporarily occupied areas. No casualties.
Interception: On 12 November 2024, Ukrainian forces shot down Russian drones over Mykolaiv region (coded to Mykolaiv).
Interception: On 15 November 2024, Ukrainian military forces intercepted 25 Russian kamikaze-drones over several locations, some over the Mykolaiv region (coded to Mykolaiv, Mykolaiv).

On 16 November 2024, Russian forces launched a drone strike at Mykolaiv, Mykolaiv region. 2 civilians was killed, 7 injured. 56 residential buildings were damaged, one private house was destroyed to the ground. One car was also destroyed and three other cars were damaged.
Interception: On 17 November 2024, Ukrainian forces shot down Russian drones and missiles over Mykolaiv region (coded to Mykolaiv).
On 17 November 2024, Russian air forces carried out drone strikes at Mykolaiv. 2 private houses were damaged. 2 civilians were killed and 7 civilians were injured.

Interception: On 19 November 2024, Russian Forces launched 87 Shahed and unspecified strike drones at targets in Ukraine. Ukrainian Forces intercepted 51 drones, some of them over Mykolaiv region (coded to Mykolaiv, Mykolaiv). 30 more Russian drones were lost in Ukrainian airspace suspectedly due to Ukrainian electronic warfare (EW) interference. No casualties.

Property destruction: Around 19 November 2024 (as reported), according to the SBU and the police, two men, aged 15 and 20, set fire to an Ukrposhta office in Odesa (coded separately) and in Mykolaiv, following Russian commands. The men were arrested together with a 17-year-old man involved in an explosion in Kyiv (coded separately).
Interception: On 20 November 2024, Ukrainian military forces intercepted 1 'Shahed' drone over the Mykolaiv region (coded to Mykolaiv, Mykolaiv).

Interception: On 25 November 2024, Russian Forces launched 145 Shahed and unspecified strike drones at targets in Ukraine. Ukrainian Forces intercepted 71 drones, some of them over Mykolaiv region (coded to Mykolaiv, Mykolaiv). 71 more Russian drones were lost in Ukrainian airspace suspectedly due to Ukrainian electronic warfare (EW) interference. No casualties.

Interception: On 26 November 2024, Russian Forces launched a record number of drones against Ukraine - 188 Shahed and other unspecified drones (suspectedly decoy drones). Ukrainian Forces intercepted 76 drones, some of them over Mykolaiv region (coded to Mykolaiv, Mykolaiv). 95 more Russian drones were lost in Ukrainian airspace suspectedly due to Ukrainian electronic warfare (EW) interference. No casualties.
On 28 November 2024, Russian forces conducted a strike with an unidentified weapons system in Mykolaiv, Mykolaiv. An unidentified explosion was reported. Casualties unknown.
On 29 November 2024, Russian military forces fired a ballistic missile at the Mykolaiv district (coded to Mykolaiv, Mykolaiv). There were no casualties.
Interception: On 3 December 2024, Ukrainian Forces intercepted 22 Russian drones, some of them over Mykolaiv region (coded to Mykolaiv, Mykolaiv). No casualties.
Property destruction: On 11 December 2024, according to the police, four men aged 14 to 18 set fire to relay cabinets in Mykolaiv, following orders coming from Russia.

Property destruction: Around 11 December 2024 (as reported), according to the Security Service, a man recruited by Russians set fire to a transformer in Mykolaiv, Mykolaiv, and recorded the arson. The man was quickly arrested.
Interception: On 13 December 2024, Ukrainian military forces intercepted a Russian cruise missile over the Mykolaiv region (coded to Mykolaiv, Mykolaiv).
On 15 December 2024, Russian air forces carried out drone strikes at Mykolaiv. Energy infrastructure was damaged. 3 civilians were injured.
Interception: On 15 December 2024, Ukrainian forces shot down Russian drones over Mykolaiv region (coded to Mykolaiv).
On 17 December 2024, explosions were reported (likely due to Russian Forces launching a ballistic missile) in the area of Mykolaiv, Mykolaiv. Casualties unknown.

Interception: On 19 December 2024, Ukrainian forces engaged Russian drones and missiles above Mykolaiv Oblast (coded as Mykolaiv, Mykolaiv.) 45 Shahed drones and drones of other types were shot down above Poltava, Sumy, Kharkiv, Kyiv, Khmelnytskyi, Chernihiv, Cherkasy, Kirovohrad, Dnipropetrovsk, and Mykolaiv. 40 other drones were interdicted with electronic warfare systems and lost.

unesco_site: Complex of the Sudak Fortress Monuments of the 6th  16th c.
notes: Interception: On 25 August 2023, explosions were reported near Sudak, Crimea. Russian sources claimed to have intercepted a wave of Ukrainian drones.

On 29 January 2018, an elderly woman and her grandson were wounded by an explosive device that went off near a pharmacy in Kharkiv. The explosion occurred when the woman opened a plastic bag, which was lying on the stairs of the pharmacy. Police officers said that the package may have contained a directional hand grenade and bearings.

Property destruction: On 4 July 2018, unidentified individuals broke into the office of LGBT centre 'PrideHub' in Kharkiv, released pepper spray and threw a smoke grenade damaging the property of the organisation.

On 12 July 2018, six people attacked and beat two members of nationalist organisation Svitanok in Kharkiv. The attackers broke one of the victims' jaw. The victims did not rule out that the attack was triggered by their activities against some institutions, including repeatedly exposing some of the Kharkiv companies for their use of 'separatist' music or symbolism.

On 20 August 2018, an unidentified man started shooting at the doors of the city council in Kharkiv, then came inside and shot several times at the guards of the building, heavily wounding one of them. The shootout continued when the police arrived. The attacker and one of the police officers were killed. The reasons for the attack remain unclear.
Property destruction: On 25 August 2018, unidentified individuals set fire to a car of a deputy of the regional council in Kharkiv. The car was damaged, but there were no injuries.
On 4 September 2018, in Kharkiv, an unnidentified person threw IED in a civilian dwelling. Explosion injured a civilian man, 30 years old.

On 13 September 2018, in Kharkiv, ATO veteran was killed during an attempt to arrest him by Ukrainian Police and SBU. He was suspected in extortion and was shot after threats to explode a grenade. The person was a leader of one of Kharkiv's ATO Veterans groups.
On Dec. 30 2018, a civilian man was killed by a RGD-5 hand grenade explosion in Kharkiv, Ukraine.

On Jan. 12 2019, two masked men attacked Dmytro Isayev, deputy director general of the regional power distribution company Kharkivoblenergo, in the stairwell of his apartment in Kharkiv, Ukraine. The victim was stabbed in the chest several times.

On Jan. 16 2019, two unidentified persons attacked a police officer near his house in Kharkiv, Ukraine. The attackers hit the man and fired unidentified weapon in the area of his neck and head. The victim was taken to a hospital.

On 22 March 2019, the Security Services of Ukraine prevented an explosion in Kharkiv metro by removing an explosive device equivalent to 600 grams of TNT and stuffed with nails, bolt and screws. A person who planted the device was arrested.
On 29 April 2019, an unidentified individual threw a grenade in an open window of a car in Kharkiv. The driver was hospitalized in a severe condition.
On 6 May 2019, an unidentified man fired eight times at an off-duty police officer with an automatic weapon in Kharkiv, causing severe injuries.

On 15 May 2019, police officers tortured with electricity, beat and strangled a man in a police department in Kharkiv in an attempt to extract a confession. Part of the torture was performed on the victim's genitals.
On 18 May 2019, an explosive device detonated in Kharkiv, killing two civilians and wounding one.
On 20 May 2019, unidentified people set fire to a volunteers' tent 'All for victory' which informs people about the situation in Donbass in Kharkiv.
On 21 May 2019, unidentified people beat a member of the National Corps in Kharkiv with brass knuckles, breaking his skull .

On 13 June 2019, the Security Service of Ukraine detained a man recruited by the Russian Federal Security Service, as he was trying to activate an explosive device on the territory of the Kharkiv water-purifying utility complex.
As reported on 21 June, the police seized an SVT-40 rifle, 34 different grenades, a mine, 1kg TNT, 2kg smokeless powder and 380 cartridges from a man in Kharkiv.

On 25 October 2019, an unidentified individual shot dead a witness in the case of the death of the Russian ex-member of Parliament Denis Voronenkov and wounded another person in Kharkiv. When the police surrounded the attacker, he blew himself up with a grenade and died.
On 27 October 2019, the police found and seized 130 grenades, a flamethrower, grenade launchers, a rifle and machine guns near Kharkiv.

On 8 November 2019, three unidentified individuals poured brilliant green [chemical desinfectant, Zelyonka] on a deputy head of the city council's law department in Kharkiv. The deputy head was hospitalized with burn to his eyes.

On 25 November 2019, unidentified individuals planted an explosive device on the car of an attorney who is a close relative of a former deputy regional prosecutor in Kharkiv. The attorney was injured in a blast, no fatalities were reported.

On 27 December 2019, an unidentified man threw a bottle with incendiary mixture at the entrance door of the regional administration in Kharkiv, setting it on fire. Bypassing people managed to put out the fire, no injuries were reported.

On 9 January 2020, the Security Service of Ukraine arrested an individual, recruited by the Russian Federal Security Service, while he was planting an explosive device in a block of flats of a scout of the National Guard's Aidar battalion in Kharkiv.
On 20 April 2020, two unidentified individuals attacked and beat a local journalist in Kharkiv. Exact motive of the attackers is unknown.

On 25 June 2020, two people severely beat with bats a member of Party of Shariy in Kharkiv. The party representatives accuse members of National Corps as the victim had received threats from them prior to the attack. The National Corps party denies the accusations.
Property destruction: On 7 September 2020, unidentified individuals broke windows of an office of an LGBT organisation 'PrideHub' in Kharkiv.
Property destruction: On 27 September 2020, unidentified individuals fired small arms and threw stones at an empty chapel building of the Orthodox Church of Ukraine in Kharkiv.
Property destruction: On 27 September 2020, about a dozen people slashed a campaigning stand of an unspecified political party in Kharkiv.

On 26 October 2020, two unidentified individuals beat with baseball bats a former Minister of Agrarian Policy from Svoboda party near Kharkiv. The politician sought medical assistance after the attack.

On 7 November 2020, at night, two unidentified individuals fired pistols at the building of the Consulate of Azerbaijan in Kharkiv. Six shots were fired at the front door and windows of the building, no injuries were reported.
Property destruction: On 8 December 2020, two unidentified individuals damaged and doused with red paint an office of the Opposition Platform - For Life in Kharkiv.
On 25 January 2021, an unidentified individual attacked and threw a grenade at the activist who investigated illegal drug dealings in Kharkiv. The victim was hospitalized.

Weapons seizure: On 24 March 2021, the police seized a cache of weapons from LPR rebel they detained in Kharkiv region, consisting of 40 grenades, two anti-personnel mines, 20 fuses for hand grenades, almost 6 kg of plastic explosives, six electric detonators, two ignition tubes, tens of metres of detonating and flaming cords, electric wire and batteries, and more than 2,200 cartridges.
On 24 March 2021, an unidentified person attacked a journalist of Stop Corruption in Kharkiv.

Weapons seizure: On 15 April 2021, the police seized a cache of weapons from a civilian in Kharkiv, consisting of two RPG-26 grenade launchers, three PKM machine guns, an RPK machine gun and its barrel, two Luger pistols, three Walther pistols, a Glock-19 pistol with a silencer, SR-10SI pistol, AGR-47, ammunition magazines for all weapons, seven F-1 and RGD-5 grenades with fuses, 32 VOG grenades, an anti-personnel mine, two night vision devices.

Weapons seizure: On 19 April 2021, the police seized a cache of weapons in the Kharkiv region, consisting of pistols of various models, a submachine gun, seven RGD-5 grenades, two F-1 grenades, five Molotov cocktails, five silencers for weapons, about 1,000 cartridges of various calibres, metal processing machines, components for making explosives.
Property destruction: On 20 April 2021, unknown persons in Kharkiv burned the cars of two employees of the political newspaper Vremya Dobkina.
On 14 May 2021, security guards of the Acting Mayor of Kharkiv City Council attacked a journalist, when he tried to ask a question about the memorialization of Gennady Kernes, the previous Mayor.
On 2 June 2021, police officers, in the line of duty, reportedly abused their power and beat up farmers in Kharkiv region.
On 30 June 2021, an unidentified assailant fired several shots at a member of the National Corps in Kharkiv with an unidentified weapon, wounding the 31-year-old victim in the neck area.

Property destruction: On 24 October 2021, unidentified individuals set fire to a car of the deputy head of the General Inspectorate of the Office of the Prosecutor in Kharkiv. The victim connects the arson to his activities against corruption as he was working in the Corruption and Organized Crime Unit.

On 24 February 2022, Russian forces fired heavy multiple rocket launcher systems Smerch, machine guns and grenade launchers at Kharkiv. A large fuel depot caught fire at night. One municipal worker was killed, 23 civilians were wounded.

On 24 February 2022, Ukrainian and Russian military forces engaged in an armed clash on the road near Kharkiv (Kharkiv). Ukrainian forces destroyed a number of Russian tanks and armoured vehicles and inflicting losses on Russian military. Unspecified fatalities coded as 3.

On 25 February 2022, a Russian tank blocked the way to a civilian car at the entry point to Kharkiv and fired multiple shots. The Russian soldiers killed a civilian and accidentally killed another Russian soldier.
On 25 February 2022, a Ukrainian MiG-29 fighter aircraft shot down a Russian Su-27/35 fighter aircraft in Kharkiv region. The pilot evacuated, there were no casualties.

On 25 February 2022, Russian artillery loaded with cluster munition and Russian air forces attacked the zooveterenary academy, the biotechnical university, and civilian infrastructure in Kharkiv, Kharkiv. 9 civilians were killed, 37 wounded.

On 25 February 2022, there was an armed clash between Russian and Ukrainian forces near Kharkiv. Russian forces also shelled with heavy weaponry the territory near Kharkiv. A fuel storage near the city caught on fire. Ukrainian counter-battery fire destroyed at least 2 Russian MLRS systems and a MT-LB and killed at least one Russian soldier.

On 26 February 2022, Russian forces dropped cluster bombs and shelled with multiple launch rocket systems and artillery the city of Kharkiv. Residential houses were damaged. One of the shells hit a public transport station, wounding one civilian. Further casualties unknown.
On 26 February 2022, Russian forces (likely by missile strike or artillery shelling) destroyed a gas pipeline in Kharkiv city, Kharkiv. Casualties unknown.

On 27 February 2022, there was an armed clash between Russian and Ukrainian military forces in Kharkiv. Ukrainian military forces destroyed two columns of Russian forces, killing Russian soldiers. Unspecified fatalities coded as 10.
On 27 February 2022, Russian forces fired heavy weapons at Kharkiv. Residential buildings, a school and a cancer hospital were hit. Around four civilians were killed.
On 27 February 2022, Russian forces shot dead two civilian men in their home in an unspecified location in the Kharkiv region (coded to Kharkiv).

On 28 February 2022, Russian artillery loaded with cluster munitions and Russian aircrafts attacked civilian infrastructure and residential buildings in Kharkiv, Kharkiv. 9 people were killed, 37 wounded.
On 28 February 2022, Russian forces clashed with Ukrainian forces in Kharkiv. A civilian woman died and two children were wounded in the crossfire. At least 4 Russian soldiers were killed.

On 1 March 2022, Ukrainian forces fired IFVs and Javellin anti-tank weapons at Russian forces near Kharkiv. Six T-80BVM tanks were captured, destroying around 30 vehicles of 200th Russian brigade, including a 2S3 Akatsyia self-propelled gun. Casualties unknown.
On 1 March 2022, Ukrainian Military shot down several Russian aircrafts, including one which crashed near the Losk market in Kharkiv. Casualties unknown.

On 1 March 2022, in the morning, Russian air force and Russian military fired Grad missiles at the 3rd hospital, killing 8 people and wounding 6. Russian forces also fired at houses on Novobavarskyi boulevard, killing 5 people and wounding around 10, and at the Botanical Garden metro station in Kharkiv. Missile attack at the central square killed 10 people and wounded 35. In total, over 50 people were wounded and 29, including three children and one Indian student, were killed. 87 houses were ruined, including the consulate of Slovenia.

On 1 March 2022, Russian airforce fired Kalibr cruise missiles at the regional administration building and at the tank training facility in Kharkiv, triggering the explosion of the ammunition. In the evening, Russian air forces (Tu-22M strategic bombers) fired 16 missiles at the houses and barracks of the pilot training facility in Kharkiv, causing a fire. At least 15 soldiers were killed and 30 were injured.

On 2 March 2022, after midnight, Russian paratroopers attacked the military hospital in the northern part of Kharkiv and clashed with the Ukrainian forces. Around 112 people received injuries and 21 died during the last 24 hours in the whole region. [10 fatalities coded, the other 11 fatalities split among 6 events]

On 2 March 2022, Russian air force shelled a school in Saltovka neighborhood, at Holodna Hora area, on Mirnositska street in Kharkiv, damaging the school. The air force also dropped two bombs, including a thermobaric bomb, on the TV tower in the city. Russian Military forces also shelled a base of the territorial defence forces, several buildings, including a police building, the sociology university, the Tools-Making Plant, and a blind children caretaking institution in Kharkiv. The Uspensky Cathedral was also damaged. During the night, Russian Su-25 delivered strikes at the 5th thermal power plant, at the tank training facility, and at a dormitory on Klochkivskyi street in Kharkiv. Four people, all police forces, were killed, nine were injured, including civilians.
Displacement: On 2 March 2022, around 22000 civilians were evacuated from the Kharkiv region.
On 2 March 2022, Ukrainian forces shot down a Russian military plane over Kharkiv. Casualties unknown.

On 3 March 2022, Russian forces and air force fired multiple rocket launchers, tube artillery, cluster munitions, and Kalibr cruise missiles at Kharkiv, Ukraine. Civilian infrastructures and city center came under the fire. Residential buildings were damaged or ruined in Kyivskyi, Shevchenkivskyi, Moskovskyi, and Nemyshlianskyi districts of Kharkiv. At least 10 civilians were killed. Ukrainian soldiers were also wounded after Russian forces hit Shevchenko factory.
On 3 March 2022, Russian forces killed 34 civilians by shelling and airstrikes in the Kharkiv region. [20 fatalities coded, the other 14 were coded to specific locations]
On 4 March 2022, Russian forces fired cluster munitions on Zaliznychna Street in Mala-Danylivka district in Kharkiv. Two people were injured.

On 5 March 2022, the Russian military forces clashed with Ukrainian forces outside of Kharkiv. Ukrainian military forces were pushing Russian troops back to the border and destroying their tanks. They almost completely destroyed the 488th Motorized Infantry Regiment of Russian forces. Casualties unknown.

On 5 March 2022, Russian military forces shelled with heavy weapons different districts of the city of Kharkiv, destroying the infrastructure of the city, including Kharkiv Oncology Center, and at least 40 residential buildings. Casualties unknown. Russian planes also dropped heavy aerial bombs on a military community in Kharkiv, killing four servicemen and injuring more.

On 6 March 2022, as a result of the Russian airstrike, TV tower in Kharkiv was damaged, television broadcasts were temporarily suspended. As a result of the airstrike on different districts of the city, 200 civilians were wounded and eight were killed. Russian military forces also shelled the supermarket in Kharkiv, killing four more people and wounding 15. Russian military forces also shelled the Institute in Kharkiv, where the nuclear research facility is located, building of the Ministry of Internal Affairs, a building of the Ministry of Defence, and a Consulate of Albania.

On 6 March 2022, Russian forces clashed with Ukrainian forces outside Kharkiv. Russian forces shelled Kharkiv. Casualties unknown. Also, Ukrainian military forces using an anti-aircraft missile system shot down Russian Su-25 aircraft, killing the pilot.

On 7 March 2022, Russian military forces shelled with heavy weapons the city of Kharkiv. Russian forces destroyed the infrastructure of the city: transformer stations, Kharkiv Armored Plant, pipelines, water pipelines. The city Mayor reported that a lot of civilians as well as servicemen were wounded and killed. Unspecified fatalities coded as 10.
On 7 March 2022, Russian military forces killed two people who came to Kharkiv zoo to feed animals.

On 8 March 2022, Ukrainian armed forces clashed with Russian special forces near school nr.134 in Kharkiv, killing at least 18 Russian soldiers and destroying 5 armoured vehicles. Two Russian soldiers were taken prisoners.
On 8 March 2022, Russian forces shelled a tram depot and a hospital in Kharkiv (Kharkiv), destroying many tram carriages, railway tracks and equipment at the hospital. Casualties unknown.

On 8 March 2022, Russian forces, including Rosgvardia troops, fired artillery, grenade launchers, and conducted air strikes at the Oleksiivka, Pyatykhaty, Belgorodske shosse, Holodna Hora, Saltovka neighborhoods in Kharkiv. The 5th thermal power plant was affected. At least two civilians were killed.

On 9 March 2022, Russian military forces fired a missile at a private house and buildings in the Saltovka neighborhood in Kharkiv. The missile went through the roof of the house. Injuries unknown, but the residents were alive. Another shelling on a market in the Zhukovsky neighborhood killed a teenager, while another one hit the Nikolski mall. An artillery shelling on the Kharkiv police department killed 4 people and wounded 15.
On 9 March 2022, members of Right Sector's armed wing 'Ukrainian Volunteer Corps' arrested an alleged spy taking photos of military objects in Kharkiv. The fighters wounded the man during the arrest.
On 9 March 2022, Ukrainian forces destroyed four military vehicles of the Russian forces with a Stugna drone in Kharkiv region. There were no fatalities.
On 9 March 2022, Russian forces shelled Velyka Danylivka neighbourhood in Kharkiv (Kharkiv). As a result, a fire broke out damaging a gas distribution pipeline. Casualties unknown.

On 10 March 2022, throughout the whole day Russian forces shelled various locations of the city of Kharkiv. Kharkiv Institute of Physics and Technology was shelled as a result of which fire broke out as well as a rocket exploded near a synagogue where about 100 people were sheltered. Civilian infrastructures were shelled as well. There are casualties among civilians. Unspecified fatalities coded as 3.
On 10 March 2022, a saboteur group of Russian forces that attempted to enter Kharkiv was neutralized by Ukrainian forces. At least 2 servicemen died, the number is possibly higher.
On 11 March 2022, throughout the whole day Russian forces shelled various locations of the city of Kharkiv. One civilian died.
Defusal: On 11 March 2022, Ukrainian State Emergency Service specialists safely removed several fragments of Russian 'Smerch' MLRS rockets with cluster munitions in Kharkiv (Kharkiv).

On 12 March 2022, there was an armed clash between Russian forces and the Ukrainian military forces near Kharkiv. After suffering losses Russian forces withdrew the remaining troops to the territory of Russia to renew combat readiness. Unspecified casualties coded as 10.
On 12 March 2022, Russian forces shelled with fired multiple launch rocket systems different districts of Kharkiv, hitting an ambulance. One health worker was wounded.

On 13 March 2022, Russian forces shelled with fired multiple launch rocket systems different city districts of Kharkiv such as Saltivka and Novi Budynky. At least 1 person was killed and 3 wounded, further casualties unknown.

On 14 March 2022, Russian forces fired 'Iskander' missiles at Kharkiv and damaged civilian infrastructure in the center. The rockets were fired from the territory of the Russian Federation. At least 7 people were killed. It was also reported that the car of volunteers 'Help Army' was hit by the fire and one person died and one was injured.
On 15 March 2022, Ukrainian forces clashed with Russian army in Kharkiv suburbs. Casualties unknown.
Around 15 March 2022 (month of), a Russian soldier repeatedly raped a 29-year-old woman in Kharkiv region, and killed her old mother, when the daughter refused to go to Russia with the soldier.

On 16 March 2022, Russian forces launched about 50 missiles at various districts of Kharkiv. Russian forces hit a school building in Kharkiv, injuring one person, and the Barabashovo market in Kharkiv, which caused a fire. Three people were killed, five were wounded.
On 16 March 2022, Ukrainian forces destroyed a column of Russian forces with artillery fire near Kharkiv. The Russian side suffered heavy losses. Unspecified fatalities coded as 10.

On 17 March 2022, Russian forces shelled the Barabashovo market in Kharkiv with BM-21 Grad as a result of which a fire broke out. While putting out the fire, one member of the State Emergency Service died and one was wounded. Additionally, earlier in the day, Russian forces also shelled other parts of Kharkiv including a church and civilian houses.
On 17 March 2022, Ukrainian forces shot down two Russian airplanes in the Kharkiv region. Casualties unknown.
Interception: On 17 March 2022, the Ukrainian air defense forces shot down a Russian drone in the Kharkiv region.

On 18 March 2022, Russian forces fired missiles at the Barabashovo market, the administration academy, and several residential buildings and houses in Kharkiv. A state emergency employee died after repeated shelling during a rescue mission. 11 people, including a firefighter, were wounded.
On 19 March 2022, Russian forces shelled the Industrial District in Kharkiv, killing 1 child.
On 20 March 2022, Russian forces shelled the Industrial District in Kharkiv, killing 5 civilians.

On 21 March 2022, Russian forces carried out artillery shelling of the city of Kharkiv, hitting a prison and residential buildings. As a result of the shelling, a 95-year-old former prisoner of Buchenwald died. Further casualties unknown.
On 22 March 2022, Russian forces shelled Kharkiv with many weapons. Civilian infrastructure was damaged. Casualties unknown.
On 23 March 2022, Russian forces fired artillery at Kharkiv. Casualties unknown. A Russian cruise missile was also shot down in the sky over Kharkiv by Ukrainian forces.
Defusal: On 23 March 2022, Ukrainian State Emergency Service specialists safely defused several Russian unexploded 'Smerch' and 'Uragan' MLRS rockets with cluster munition in Kharkiv (Kharkiv).

Interception: On 23 March 2022, Russian air defense intercepted Ukrainian drones near Kharkiv, Kharkiv. Russian sources reported interception of 9 drones near Kyiv, Izium, Kharkiv, Chernihiv, and Sumy.

On 24 March 2022, Ukrainian forces through an artillery attack fired on the Russian 59th Tank Regiment in the Kharkiv region as a result of which the Russian side suffered significant losses both in manpower as well as military equipment. Unspecified fatalities coded as 10.
On 24 March 2022, the Ukrainian forces shot down a Russian Su-34 in the direction of Kharkiv. No information about what happened to the pilot.

On 24 March 2022, at night, Russian forces shelled Kharkiv from ships of the Black Sea Fleet after which, later in the day, Russian forces fired on civilians queuing for humanitarian aid as a result of which 6 people were killed and 15 wounded. Russian forces shelled Zhukovsky district of Kharkiv as a result of which multiple civilian infrastructures were damaged and a fire broke out. Casualties unknown.
Interception: On 24 March 2022, Ukrainian forces shot down one Russian drone in the Kharkiv region.
Defusal: On 24 March 2022, Ukrainian State Emergency Service specialists safely removed an unexploded Russian 'Smerch' MLRS rocket embedded in the road in Kharkiv (Kharkiv).

On 25 March 2022, Ukrainian forces clashed with Russian forces near Kharkiv, taking control of an electronic warfare system truck and killing around 50 Russian soldiers working around it. 17 soldiers were taken prisoners, 15 of which were from NAF forces.

On 25 March 2022, during the night, Russian forces fired artillery, grenade launchers, tanks, and Grad and Uragan missiles at the airport and the Metro supermarket in Kharkiv. 6 people died and 17 were wounded. In the morning, Russian forces fired reactive Kalibr missiles at a clinic and a humanitarian aid center in the Osnovyansk district of the city where one civilian was killed and one was injured, as well as they fired at the Barabashovo market.

On 26 March 2022, Russian forces carried out an artillery shelling of the residential districts of Kharkiv. As a result of shelling, five people were killed in Osnovyanskyy district. Further casualties unknown. Russian forces also shelled a nuclear facility in the city.

On 27 March 2022, Russian military shelled from Smerch systems and fired cluster bombs at Ukrainian positions in Kharkiv region. Russian forces fired thermobaric or incendiary shells. Casualties unknown.
On 27 March 2022, Russian forces shelled Kharkiv. They also shelled at Drobytskyy Yar in Kharkiv, the site of mass shootings of civilians by Nazi occupation troops in 1941-1942. Casualties unknown.
On 28 March 2022, Ukrainian air force shot down Russian aircraft and drone in Kharkiv region. Casualties unknown.
On 28 March 2022, Russian forces shelled various residential areas of Kharkiv as a result of which civilian infrastructure was damaged and at least 1 civilian was wounded.
On 29 March 2022, Russian forces continued to fire artillery and drop air bombs at Kharkiv. Casualties unknown.

On 31 March 2022, Ukrainian air defense forces shot down 1 fighter and 3 bomber Russian planes in the Kharkiv region. Casualties unknown.

On 31 March 2022, Russian forces shelled Kharkiv throughout the whole day. Missiles fell in the city center and residential neighborhoods. Firefighters rescued 2 women from their apartments, no casualties.

On 3 April 2022, Russian forces clashed with the Ukrainian Army near Kharkiv and suffered considerable losses. Significant losses coded as 10 fatalities. Also, a Russian airplane SU-24 was shot down.
On 3 April 2022, Russian forces shelled residential districts in Kharkiv. 7 people were killed and at least 34 injured.

On 5 April 2022, Ukrainian air forces shot down a Russian Ka-52 helicopter with Stugna-P ATGM in Kharkiv region. Casualties unknown.

On 7 April 2022, Russian forces shelled residential areas of Kharkiv throughout the whole day as a result of which fire broke out in a high-rise building and a shopping mall. 1 civilian was killed and 14 were wounded.

On 11 April 2022, Russian forces shelled Kharkiv using multiple rocket launchers, artillery, and mortars. As a result of the shelling, eight people, including a child, were killed and dozens were wounded.

On 12 April 2022, Russian forces continued to fire artillery and multiple rocket launchers to destroy residential areas in Kharkiv, killing one child. Russian forces also used cluster munitions. Further casualties unknown.

On 14 April 2022, as a result of Russian shelling of the Kharkiv region 1 Ukrainian civilian was killed and 8 were wounded. (coded to Kharkiv as the exact location is unknown)

Ukrainian Forces intercepted 52 drones, some of them over Kharkiv region (coded to Kharkiv, Kharkiv). 50 more Russian drones were lost in Ukrainian airspace suspectedly due to Ukrainian electronic warfare (EW) interference. No casualties.
Defusal: Around 2 December 2024 (week of), State Emergency Service of Ukraine defused 516 unexploded ordnances (UXOs) in Kharkiv region (coded to Kharkiv, Kharkiv). No casualties.

Property destruction: Around 2 December 2024 (as reported), according to the SBU, two boys, aged 16 and 17, set fire to two military recruitment center buildings in Kharkiv, following a command from Russians. The boys were arrested before fleeing to Odesa.

Interception: On 5 December 2024, Ukrainian forces engaged Russian Shahed drones above Kharkiv Oblast (coded as Kharkiv, Kharkiv.) 30 Russian drones were intercepted above Kharkiv, Poltava, Sumy, Chernihiv, Cherkasy, Kirovhrad, Zhytomyr, Vinnytsia, Kyiv, and Khmelnytsky Oblasts. 12 drones disappeared and 1 disappeared near or in Belarus.
Interception: On 6 December 2024, Ukrainian military forces intercepted 32 Russian drones across multiple locations, some over the Kharkiv region (coded to Kharkiv, Kharkiv).
Interception: On 8 December 2024, Ukrainian forces shot down Russian drones over Kharkiv region (coded to Kharkiv).

On 8 December 2024, according to the police, a 15-year-old boy and a 15-year-old girl planted an explosive under a car in Kharkiv, damaging a police building in the Slobidskyi district of the city. No casualties. According to law enforcement, the children were recruited by Russians.

On 9 December 2024, according to the police, a 15-year-old boy and a 15-year-old girl planted explosives near a police station in Kholodnohirskyi district of Kharkiv, Kharkiv, which, upon remote detonation, damaged the police building. No casualties. According to the law enforcement bodies, the children were recruited by Russians.
On 13 December 2024, Russian kamikaze-drone struck a residential building in the Industrial district in Kharkiv, Kharkiv. There were no casualties.

Around 13 December 2024 (as reported), Ukrainian border guards clashed with and stopped a Russian reconnaissance and sabotage group in the Kharkiv region (coded to Kharkiv, Kharkiv). Casualties unknown.
On 13 December 2024, Russian forces (likely with drones) struck the Kharkiv district (coded to Kharkiv, Kharkiv). Casualties unknown.
On 14 December 2024, Ukrainian Border Guard servicemen launched drone strikes at several Russian positions on Kharkiv axis (coded to Kharkiv, Kharkiv region), destroying 7 hideouts and an ammo depot.
Interception: On 15 December 2024, Ukrainian forces shot down Russian drones over Kharkiv region (coded to Kharkiv).
On 15 December 2024, Russian forces launched 'Iskander-M' missiles at Kharkiv. 1 civilian was injured.

On 15 December 2024, Russian forces shelled Ukrainian positions near Kharkiv. According to Russian sources, more than 85 Ukrainian servicemen were killed near Lyptsi, Vovchansk and Kharkiv [Russian MoD reported 85 fatalities. Coded as 10 fatalities split across 3 events. 3 fatalities coded to this event].

Property destruction: Around 15 December 2024, according to prosecutors, a previously convicted 30-year-old man and 21-year-old set fire to a car belonging to a soldier in Kharkiv, Kharkiv, following commands from Russian special services.

Interception: On 16 December 2024, Russian Forces launched 49 Shahed and other drones (suspectedly referring to decoy drones) at targets in Ukraine. Ukrainian Forces intercepted 27 drones, some of them over Kharkiv region (coded to Kharkiv, Kharkiv). 19 more drones got lost likely due to Ukrainian electronic warfare (EW) interference. No casualties.
On 18 December 2024, Russian forces used the UAV 'Molniia' to attack Kharkiv, Kharkiv. There were no casualties.

Interception: On 19 December 2024, Ukrainian forces engaged Russian drones and missiles above Kharkiv Oblast (coded as Kharkhiv, Kharkiv.) 45 Shahed drones and drones of other types were shot down above Poltava, Sumy, Kharkiv, Kyiv, Khmelnytskyi, Chernihiv, Cherkasy, Kirovohrad, Dnipropetrovsk, and Mykolaiv. 40 other drones were interdicted with electronic warfare systems and lost.
On 20 December 2024, Russian drones struck Kharkiv, Kharkiv, damaging residential buildings and critical infrastructure. 3 civilians were wounded.

notes: Property destruction: On 11 January 2018, unidentified individuals set fire to a car in Kiev belonging to the head of an initiative group for public control over the investigation into the murder of human rights activist Iryna Nozdrovska. The fire spread to another car parked nearby. No injuries were reported.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Other: On 18 January 2018, Ukraine's parliament in Kiev has passed a bill on de-occupation of Donbas region. The supporters of the bill, including President Poroshenko, say it will help Kyiv restore control over areas in the east that are held by Russia-backed separatists. The bill defines Donetsk and Luhansk regions as 'temporarily occupied territories', contrary to the autonomy granted to them in the Minsk agreement, and labels Russia as 'aggressor'.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 25 January 2018, Ukraine presented the first cyber security centre in Kiev, strengthening its capacity to combat cyber crime. The centre was opened thanks to cooperation with Nato and the SBU.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 26 January 2018, in Kyiv, an additional 50 Canadian servicemen have arrived in Ukraine to train the country's troops as part of the UNIFIER mission, Lt. Col. Kristopher Reeves, commander of the Canadian army's Joint Task Force-Ukraine stated.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 7 February 2018, in Kiev, members of the National Corps attacked two men who were planning to distribute 'antifascist' leaflets. The victims claimed to be members of the Communist Party from western Ukraine.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 8 February 2018, a journalist was injured after gas was dispersed in the Vesti office as the National Agency for Identifying, Tracing and Managing Assets Obtained through Corruption and Other Crimes took control of the editorial offices of the Vesti newspaper in Kiev. unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 12 February 2018, State Border Guards detained Mikheil Saakashvili, the leader of the New Forces Movement Party in Ukraine and ex-president of Georgia while he was dining in a restaurant in Kiev. Saakashvili faces extradition.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 16 February 2018, 2018 Police Forces of Ukraine seized over 100 improvised explosive devices, bottles with an unidentified flammable substance, and a large amount of marijuana during the searches at the home of one Kiev resident.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

She is suspected of committing these crimes in collusion with Oleksandr Ruban, who was also detained earlier.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 28 March 2018, unidentified individuals, presumably belonging to far right groups, attacked a civilian in Kiev - Pecherskyi. They sprayed pepper spray into his face after he came out the cinema building where a Docudays human rights film festival was held.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Other: On 30 March 2018, Ukraine has expelled 13 Russian diplomats from the territory of the country in connection with a nerve gas attack against former double agent Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia in Salisbury on March 4 [coded to Kiev].

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Weapons seizure: Around 20 April 2018, the Security Service of Ukraine exposed an organized group in Kiev that established the illegal export of weapons and ammunition from the ATO area. During the investigation it was established that former members of one of the volunteer battalions sent weapons and parts of ammunition for assembling and manufacturing in one of the workshops in Kiev to be used for further re-sale in the capital region and to members of criminal circles throughout Ukraine. The SBU seized four anti-tank grenade launchers, 30 grenades, two large-calibre projectiles, three kilograms of plastid, three detonators, six rifles, three automatic weapons, 37 pistols and traumatic guns and almost 15,000 ammunition rounds.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Weapons seizure: Around 20 April 2018 (as reported), the Security Service of Ukraine stopped the activities of an international group that supplied weapons to Ukraine from Europe and the United States. During the investigation it was established that a resident of Kiev had established a channel for the supply of spare parts for pistols and automatic devices which were brought into Ukraine by couriers and later assembled in workshops for use in combat. The SBU seized three machine guns, three assault rifles, two rifles, seven submachine guns, 30 pistols and revolvers, eight grenade launchers, 32 grenades, five mines, 3,240 ammunition rounds and assembly kits pistols.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Weapons seizure: On 1 May 2018, Ukrainian law enforcers have discovered a package with arms and ammunition on Trukhaniv Island in Kiev which contained four grenades, detonators, five TNT blocks, 10 projectiles for a grenade launcher, five cartridges for a rifle and about 1,500 rounds of ammunition.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Security measures: On 8 May 2018, the Security Service of Ukraine carried out searches at home of the Ukrainian Communist Party leader Petro Symonenko in Kiev and recovered campaign leaflets calling for constitutional change or government overthrow or takeover, and seized items looking like a Stechkin pistol with a silencer and 120 cartridges. Symonenko had been summoned for questioning as part of a criminal inquiry into 'actions aimed at violent change or overthrow of the constitutional system or seizure of government power' and 'high treason,' according to the SBU spokeswoman Olena Hytlyanska. Later in the day SBU officers raided the homes of senior Communists in and around Kyiv and recovered campaign materials containing banned Communist symbols.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 15 May 2018, the Security Service of Ukraine (SBU) launched a large-scale operation against the employees of RIA Novosti Ukraine accusing them of participating in a 'hybrid information war' waged by Russia against Ukraine. Its Chief Editor, Kirill Vyshinsky, who has dual Russian-Ukrainian citizenship, was detained in Kiev - Shevchenkivskyi and more than 40 agency's employees have been summoned to the SBU for interrogation.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 17 May 2018, unidentified individuals attacked a Donbas veteran in Kiev who had become famous for his travel blog, in particular, after he published a video of arguing with and spitting in the face of a pro-Kremlin Russian journalist. The victim sustained injuries to his head.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 30 May 2018, in Kiev, Ukrainian authorities detained a Ukrainian citizen, Borys Herman, accused of being recruited by Russia's secret services to organize a murder plot against self-exiled Russian reporter and Kremlin critic Arkady Babchenko. Ukraine's Security Service (SBU) says it thwarted the planned killing by working together with Babchenko to fake his death. Ukrainian authorities also said a total of up to 30 people in Ukraine had been targeted for killing as part of the alleged Russian plot. Both SBU officials and Babchenko have defended their decision to fake Babchenko's death - rejecting criticism from reporters and journalism advocates who warned that it has undermined the credibility of law enforcement agencies and independent media organizations.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Around 21 June 2018 (between 18 June - 24 June), more than 20 LGBT activists and volunteers of the March of Equality were assaulted and beaten in Kiev.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Property destruction: On 6 August 2018, unidentified individuals tried to break into the house of a TV journalist and her parents outside Kiev by breaking the door, however fled when neighbours called the police. One of the attackers was identified as a member of a Chechen criminal group and was placed on the wanted list.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Weapons seizure: On 15 August 2018, in Kiev, law enforcers uncovered an arms cache in a garage cooperative, belonging to a former Kiev-2 battalion serviceman, with a large quantity of firearms, ammunition and explosives.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 4 September 2018, in Kyiv, Serhiy Chemes, a 'hired heavy' who was charged with torturing and murdering Ukrainian anti-government protesters during Euromaidan in 2014, was sentenced to three years and three months in prison after agreeing to testify against his former accomplices

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 4 September 2018, A court in Kiev has prolonged the arrest of parliament member Nadezhda Savchenko, accused of plotting terrorist attacks, till October 30, Savchenko's lawyer Alexander Shadrin told TASS. The court thereby dismissed the lawyer's request for Savchenko's release on parole. Shadrin said the defence will protest this decision. The Ukrainian parliament on March 22 stripped Savchenko of immunity and authorized her detention and arrest. First, Savchenko was detained and arrested for two months. The arrest was prolonged again and the request for easing the restrictive measure was turned down. Investigators suspect Savchenko of plotting terrorist attacks inside the parliament's building and the government compound in Kiev.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 6 September 2018, in Kyiv, unidentified youth group stabbed a young man 3 times with knife due to him looking 'gay'. 5 suspects were detained.

Over these four years, police have registered 60 cases of seizing Crimean weapons from rebels, including 51 assault rifles, 15 pistols, two grenade launchers and one carbine. Police have opened a criminal case against the Russian Federation according to Part 2, Article 438 of the Criminal Code on using internationally illegal warfare methods.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

According to police information, the weapons were brought to Kiev by an army volunteer in 2014-16.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

The parties also agreed to start the disengagement of forces in Zolote and Petrovskoye areas on 7 October [coded to Kiev, Ukraine].

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 13 November 2019, at night, four unidentified people shot several times at windows of a shop of a Russian footwear brand and painted an ethnic slur in front of it.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Security measures: On 17 March 2020, the government of Ukraine in Kiev enacted measures to limit the spread of coronavirus - including a ban on gatherings exceeding 10 people and shutting down stores and other public places except those that sell food or medicine. On 22 May 2020, the government of Ukraine eased the quarantine restrictions.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Other: On 18 January 2018, Ukraine's parliament in Kiev has passed a bill on de-occupation of Donbas region. The supporters of the bill, including President Poroshenko, say it will help Kyiv restore control over areas in the east that are held by Russia-backed separatists. The bill defines Donetsk and Luhansk regions as 'temporarily occupied territories', contrary to the autonomy granted to them in the Minsk agreement, and labels Russia as 'aggressor'.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 25 January 2018, Ukraine presented the first cyber security centre in Kiev, strengthening its capacity to combat cyber crime. The centre was opened thanks to cooperation with Nato and the SBU.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 26 January 2018, in Kyiv, an additional 50 Canadian servicemen have arrived in Ukraine to train the country's troops as part of the UNIFIER mission, Lt. Col. Kristopher Reeves, commander of the Canadian army's Joint Task Force-Ukraine stated.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 7 February 2018, in Kiev, members of the National Corps attacked two men who were planning to distribute 'antifascist' leaflets. The victims claimed to be members of the Communist Party from western Ukraine.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 8 February 2018, a journalist was injured after gas was dispersed in the Vesti office as the National Agency for Identifying, Tracing and Managing Assets Obtained through Corruption and Other Crimes took control of the editorial offices of the Vesti newspaper in Kiev. This was done under criminal proceedings against the former minister for taxes and levies, who is accused of corruption.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 12 February 2018, State Border Guards detained Mikheil Saakashvili, the leader of the New Forces Movement Party in Ukraine and ex-president of Georgia while he was dining in a restaurant in Kiev. Saakashvili faces extradition.

notes: On 16 February 2018, 2018 Police Forces of Ukraine seized over 100 improvised explosive devices, bottles with an unidentified flammable substance, and a large amount of marijuana during the searches at the home of one Kiev resident.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 21 March 2018, an Azerbaijani journalist was attacked at his residence in Kiev by unknown persons, which resulted in several injuries.

notes: On 22 March 2018, an MP Nadia Savchenko was arrested by Security Service of Ukraine in the building of the Verkhovna Rada in Kiev - Pecherskyi on suspicion of committing such crimes as the creation of a 'terrorist' group or a 'terrorist' organization, encroachment on the life of a statesman and attempted 'terrorist' attack. She is suspected of committing these crimes in collusion with Oleksandr Ruban, who was also detained earlier.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Other: On 30 March 2018, Ukraine has expelled 13 Russian diplomats from the territory of the country in connection with a nerve gas attack against former double agent Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia in Salisbury on March 4 [coded to Kiev].

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Weapons seizure: Around 20 April 2018, the Security Service of Ukraine exposed an organized group in Kiev that established the illegal export of weapons and ammunition from the ATO area. During the investigation it was established that former members of one of the volunteer battalions sent weapons and parts of ammunition for assembling and manufacturing in one of the workshops in Kiev to be used for further re-sale in the capital region and to members of criminal circles throughout Ukraine. The SBU seized four anti-tank grenade launchers, 30 grenades, two large-calibre projectiles, three kilograms of plastid, three detonators, six rifles, three automatic weapons, 37 pistols and traumatic guns and almost 15,000 ammunition rounds.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Weapons seizure: Around 20 April 2018 (as reported), the Security Service of Ukraine stopped the activities of an international group that supplied weapons to Ukraine from Europe and the United States. During the investigation it was established that a resident of Kiev had established a channel for the supply of spare parts for pistols and automatic devices which were brought into Ukraine by couriers and later assembled in workshops for use in combat. The SBU seized three machine guns, three assault rifles, two rifles, seven submachine guns, 30 pistols and revolvers, eight grenade launchers, 32 grenades, five mines, 3,240 ammunition rounds and assembly kits pistols.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Weapons seizure: On 1 May 2018, Ukrainian law enforcers have discovered a package with arms and ammunition on Trukhaniv Island in Kiev which contained four grenades, detonators, five TNT blocks, 10 projectiles for a grenade launcher, five cartridges for a rifle and about 1,500 rounds of ammunition.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Security measures: On 8 May 2018, the Security Service of Ukraine carried out searches at home of the Ukrainian Communist Party leader Petro Symonenko in Kiev and recovered campaign leaflets calling for constitutional change or government overthrow or takeover, and seized items looking like a Stechkin pistol with a silencer and 120 cartridges. Symonenko had been summoned for questioning as part of a criminal inquiry into 'actions aimed at violent change or overthrow of the constitutional system or seizure of government power' and 'high treason,' according to the SBU spokeswoman Olena Hytlyanska. Later in the day SBU officers raided the homes of senior Communists in and around Kyiv and recovered campaign materials containing banned Communist symbols.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 15 May 2018, the Security Service of Ukraine (SBU) launched a large-scale operation against the employees of RIA Novosti Ukraine accusing them of participating in a 'hybrid information war' waged by Russia against Ukraine. Its Chief Editor, Kirill Vyshinsky, who has dual Russian-Ukrainian citizenship, was detained in Kiev - Shevchenkivskyi and more than 40 agency's employees have been summoned to the SBU for interrogation.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 17 May 2018, unidentified individuals attacked a Donbas veteran in Kiev who had become famous for his travel blog, in particular, after he published a video of arguing with and spitting in the face of a pro-Kremlin Russian journalist. The victim sustained injuries to his head.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 30 May 2018, in Kiev, Ukrainian authorities detained a Ukrainian citizen, Borys Herman, accused of being recruited by Russia's secret services to organize a murder plot against self-exiled Russian reporter and Kremlin critic Arkady Babchenko. Ukraine's Security Service (SBU) says it thwarted the planned killing by working together with Babchenko to fake his death. Ukrainian authorities also said a total of up to 30 people in Ukraine had been targeted for killing as part of the alleged Russian plot. Both SBU officials and Babchenko have defended their decision to fake Babchenko's death - rejecting criticism from reporters and journalism advocates who warned that it has undermined the credibility of law enforcement agencies and independent media organizations.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Around 21 June 2018 (between 18 June - 24 June), more than 20 LGBT activists and volunteers of the March of Equality were assaulted and beaten in Kiev.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Property destruction: On 6 August 2018, unidentified individuals tried to break into the house of a TV journalist and her parents outside Kiev by breaking the door, however fled when neighbours called the police. One of the attackers was identified as a member of a Chechen criminal group and was placed on the wanted list.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Weapons seizure: On 15 August 2018, in Kiev, law enforcers uncovered an arms cache in a garage cooperative, belonging to a former Kiev-2 battalion serviceman, with a large quantity of firearms, ammunition and explosives.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 4 September 2018, in Kyiv, Serhiy Chemes, a 'hired heavy' who was charged with torturing and murdering Ukrainian anti-government protesters during Euromaidan in 2014, was sentenced to three years and three months in prison after agreeing to testify against his former accomplices

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 4 September 2018, A court in Kiev has prolonged the arrest of parliament member Nadezhda Savchenko, accused of plotting terrorist attacks, till October 30, Savchenko's lawyer Alexander Shadrin told TASS. The court thereby dismissed the lawyer's request for Savchenko's release on parole. Shadrin said the defence will protest this decision. The Ukrainian parliament on March 22 stripped Savchenko of immunity and authorized her detention and arrest. First, Savchenko was detained and arrested for two months. The arrest was prolonged again and the request for easing the restrictive measure was turned down. Investigators suspect Savchenko of plotting terrorist attacks inside the parliament's building and the government compound in Kiev.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 6 September 2018, in Kyiv, unidentified youth group stabbed a young man 3 times with knife due to him looking 'gay'. 5 suspects were detained.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 6 September 2018, The head of the National Police, Serhiy Knyazyev, has said that Russia arms rebels in east Ukraine with weapons seized during the annexation of Crimea. Over these four years, police have registered 60 cases of seizing Crimean weapons from rebels, including 51 assault rifles, 15 pistols, two grenade launchers and one carbine. Police have opened a criminal case against the Russian Federation according to Part 2, Article 438 of the Criminal Code on using internationally illegal warfare methods.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 9 September 2018, in Kyiv, an arms cache was uncovered by police in Kiev, the Interfax-Ukraine news agency reported on 9 September. It contained four grenade launchers, 2 kg of explosives and 200 AK rifle cartridges, the Kiev police said. According to police information, the weapons were brought to Kiev by an army volunteer in 2014-16.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 12 September 2018, in Kyiv, official start of procedures of creation Ukrainian (national) Orthodox Church. The event signifies a peak of struggle of Ukrainians to break away from religious monopoly of Moscow. Metropolitan Emmanuel of France, a hierarch of the Ecumenical Church of Constantinople, told the Italian Catholic agency SIR that the procedures for creating an autocephalous local [national] Church in Ukraine had begun.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 18 September 2018, in Kyiv, Kiev police have detained a man suspected of selling weapons illegally brought from the combat zone in Donbass. The man was detained while trying to sell an AKSU rifle, two hand grenades, two grenade launchers and two Skorpion submachine guns.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 28 September 2018, in Kyiv, around 30 young men, most of whom had Sich insignia on their clothes, present in the courtroom during the trial of a journalist being accused of treason. The SMM heard the young men verbally insulting the journalist and his defence team and saw small objects being thrown at them. Later, ten police officers in riot gear entered the courtroom, at which point the disruptions ceased.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 29 September 2018, in Kyiv, the office of a member of parliament had been damaged by unidentified people.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: As reported on Nov. 28 2018, in Kiev, the Security Service of Ukraine uncovered an organised group, which was assembling and illegally selling weapons, and seized 8 illegal firearms. Members of the group included a National Guard serviceman who was arrested.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On Nov. 29 2018, after the arrest of the Ukrainian blogger Oleksandr Baraboshko in Kiev, Ukraine, members of the military prosecutor's office inflicted light bodily injuries on him and tried to obtain evidence by force.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 30 November 2018, unidentified individuals followed to the house and tried to stab a Donbass veteran and members of Traditions and Order in Kyiv. The attackers cut the veteran's face and clothes with a knife and escaped.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: As reported on Dec. 14 2018, the Security Service of Ukraine confiscated 21 F-1 hand grenades, 3 RGD-5 grenades, 15 grenades for a VOG underbarrel grenade launcher and over 3 kg of TNT from a man near Kiev, Ukraine.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On Feb. 1 2019, at night, an unidentified person fired a gunshot at the windows of the regional office of the National Union of Journalists of Ukraine in the Kiev city centre.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 12 February 2019, unidentified individuals broke the window of a car of the Kiev city council from Svoboda party and the head of Sokil in Kiev, threw incendiary mixture inside and set it to fire. The car burned down, no injuries were reported.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 22 February 2019, unidentified persons burned down a car of a journalist in Kiev, Ukraine. No injuries or fatalities were reported. unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: As reported on 6 March, the police seized six pistols, four carbines, a sniper rifle, seven RGD-5 grenades, an anti-personnel mine, 642 grams of plastic explosive and 448 rounds of ammunition from a group of people in Kiev, Ukraine.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 18 March 2019, an unidentified person threw incendiary mixture setting fire to a 'Roshen' store [a corporation belonging to President Poroshenko] in the centre of Kiev. No injuries or fatalities were reported.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 21 April 2019, an unidentified man pushed a police officer away from a police car, sat in a vehicle and ran over the officer causing her serious injuries in central Kiev. The man was arrested.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 4 May 2019, a son of a former deputy mayor of Horlivka and now a member of the DPR government was shot dead in his apartment in Kiev.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 26 August 2019, unidentified individual fired grenade launcher at an office building in central Kiev. The building was damaged, no injuries or fatalities were reported. unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 29 August 2019, a former Ukrainian soldier attacked and beat an openly gay Donbass veteran in central Kiev.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 7 September 2019, Ukraine and Russia exchanged 35 prisoners from each side. Among the prisoners released by Russia are Ukrainian filmmaker Sentsov and 24 Ukrainian sailors whose imprisonment sparked numerous demonstrations in Ukraine. Among those handed over to Moscow are Ukrainian and Russian citizens involved in the conflict in Eastern Ukraine including a witness in MH17 commercial flight downing case.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 1 October 2019, the Trilateral Contact Group on Ukraine agreed on the so-called 'Steinmeier formula' during the negotiations in Minsk that foresees that a law on the special status of Donbass comes into force from the day the non-government-controlled Luhansk and Donetsk hold democratic elections in accordance with the Ukrainian law and OSCE standards. The parties also agreed to start the disengagement of forces in Zolote and Petrovskoye areas on 7 October [coded to Kiev, Ukraine].

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 13 November 2019, at night, four unidentified people shot several times at windows of a shop of a Russian footwear brand and painted an ethnic slur in front of it.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

Two arrested suspects used to fight on the side of the Ukrainian military in Donbass.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 14 April 2020, in Kyiv, the Security Service of Ukraine (SBU) counterintelligence arrested an SBU major general Shaitanov on charges of high treason: spying for the Russian FSB and arranging attacks on Ukrainian volunteers as part of the FSB's reconnaissance and sabotage operations inside Ukraine.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 7 May 2020, according to the victims, two Donbas veterans from the Azov Battalion were severely beaten by members of National Corps in Kyiv for their support of Serhiy Sternenko - a former member of Right Sector who stabbed in self-defence one of his attackers during the third attack on his life. The leader of National Corps denies these accusations, although confirms the meeting with the two veterans.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Property destruction: On 10 July 2020, members of an anarchist group set fire to a police department in Kiev-Pecherskyi. No injuries were reported.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: Property destruction: On 5 December 2024, a 26-year-old previously convicted man set fire to police vehicles in the city of Kyiv in revenge for police arresting him for curfew violation.

notes: On 6 December 2024, Russian drones attacked Kyiv, Kyiv City. The Ukrainian military intercepted 32 drones across multiple locations, some over the Kyiv region. Drones' debris damaged residential property, a garage and outbuildings. There were no casualties.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

notes: On 14 December 2024, Russian forces launched a drone strike at Kyiv region (coded to Kyiv, Kyiv region). Ukrainian air defence forces intercepted about 10 drones, but the falling debris in the Darnytskyi district damaged an enterprise and warehouses, causing a fire. Casualties unknown.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

notes: Weapons seizure: Around 15 December 2024 (month of), according to the Security Service of Ukraine, the SBU arrested a 16-year-old man who was planting an explosive device outside a military unit in the Kyiv region (coded to Kyiv). The explosive device was prepared by two women recruited by Russian services and who handed the explosive to the man.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

No casualties.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
notes: On 19 December 2024, debris from Russian drones crashed into a private home and onto train tracks on Kyiv, Kyiv City. The home was damaged. No casualties.

unesco_site: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra

notes: On 20 December 2024, Russian Kindzhal and Iskander missiles attacked Kyiv - Pecherskyi, Kyiv City, damaging a garage. No fatalities, injuries unknown.

notes: On 20 December 2024, Russian Kindzhal and Iskander missiles attacked Kyiv - Shevchenkivskyi, Kyiv City, but were intercepted by the Ukrainian military. Debris damaging an administrative buildings, embassies and a historical cathedral. No fatalities, injuries unknown.
